awd_titl_txt: CAREER: The systematic instability of risk preferences in economic decision-making
awd_abstract_narration:
Decision-making under risk affects a wide array of phenomena from retirement savings decisions, to entrepreneurial start-up rates, to the pricing of financial assets. One well-known feature of existing data is that people shift from risk seeking in some situations (e.g., buying a lottery ticket), to risk aversion in others (e.g., purchasing insurance). To explain this basic instability of risk taking, economists have recently proposed new theories in which attention directly shapes risk-taking. However, empirical work that tests these new attention-based theories has lagged substantially due to constraints on data availability. In this CAREER proposal, this problem is addressed by collecting direct measures of attention in experiments using eye-tracking and neural data to inform the mathematical modeling of behavior and decision processes. The work will also use proprietary data from the field to test the generalizability of the main findings from the controlled laboratory experiments. Ultimately, the goal of this work is to integrate research on attention into standard economic analyses, which will dramatically increase explanatory power of current economic models and inform public policy. The educational component of this project will target several different levels of education from middle school students to PhD candidates.  The PI will create a new undergraduate course in neuroeconomics, offer summer research internships to undergraduates, and train a business school PhD student in cutting edge methods in behavioral and neuroeconomics. There will also be a significant outreach component in which the PI will work with a STEM elementary school to broaden access to basic principles of behavioral economics. 
The overall objective of the proposed research is to develop novel experimental tests of attention-based theories of economic choice. There are three specific research goals. First, the PI will conduct an experimental test, using eye tracking data, to characterize the attention function that maps monetary payoffs into measures of attention. Under several of the theories to be tested, there is an assumption that attention to monetary payoffs is deployed in a manner similar to how attention is allocated to sensory stimuli (e.g., a visual photo). The experiment will be designed to test these properties, which will provide much needed guidance for a rapidly growing theoretical literature. Second, the PI will experimentally test for broader sources of attention allocation to payoffs -- including visual properties of the choice set. The PI will also test for feedback loops between attention and risk preferences. Third, the PI will test whether the attention mechanism that affects risk taking in a controlled laboratory setting can be generalized to high-stakes environments in the field.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The outcomes of this project have helped to advance our understanding of economic decision-making under risk. The standard economic model typically begins by positing that consumers and investors have stable preferences. This implies that when a consumer or investor is faced with a particular product or investment opportunity, their choice can be well-predicted by the characteristics of the product or the investment, and the consumer's or investor's preferences. This project has made substantial progress on elucidating the scope of this elegant model of stable preferences. First and foremost, research findings from the project have demonstrated that choice is unstable, but in a systematic manner that is explained by core principles from cognitive science. The research project has identified and tested conditions under which choice biases should appear and when they should not. For example, a paper from this research project finds that one of the most classic puzzles from choice under risk, the so-called ''Allais Paradox'', does not universally obtain; rather, it is generated only under some conditions where payoffs are salient and thus attract attention. Another important theme of the research project has been to demonstrate both theoretically and experimentally that many behaviors which economists have typically interpreted as biased, may actually stem from optimal allocation of scarce cognitive resources. Several papers from this project - from risky choice to strategic decision-making - have examined how ''efficient coding'' of economic variables can generate behavior that depends systematically on past experience. While these effects could plausibly be interpreted as ''irrational'' and subject to recency bias, the theoretical lens through which we interpret the data suggests that decision-makers are optimally relying on past knowledge of the environment to make decisions that are in their best economic interest. The project has resulted in six manuscripts, three of which have already been published in top economics and finance outlets.

The broader impacts of the project have largely been focused on educational activities for undergraduate, masters, and doctoral students, and to some extent, K-5 students. The project has led to the development of three new university courses on the topics of behavioral and neuro economics and finance. The first course was developed for undergraduates in 2019, and is now taught at capacity in both semesters to students from a variety of different majors including business, psychology, neuroscience, music and journalism. The course is highly interdisciplinary and has formed the basis for several students to pursue graduate study in this field. At the graduate level, the course has spurred the development of multiple doctoral dissertations. The first student to take the course in 2019 and write a dissertation on course topics graduated last month and will begin as an assistant professor at the London School of Economics. Information about the research findings from the project have been disseminated through roughly 50 presentations at a broad set of academic departments both nationally and internationally.
